reviewText:
It's the age-old story we're all so familiar with. A little kitty has gone out for a night on the lash with its mates, gotten absolutely f*cking slaughtered, against all odds, has somehow managed to stumble its way back home again in one piece, but wouldn't you know it, has only gone and forgotten their keys and locked themselves out. Euurrrgh, classic kitty! It's a good job you're still at home inside, then, and are able to set up an elaborate array of contraptions that will eventually open the door for our sh*t-faced feline and let it sleep off its inevitable hangover!

Let the Cat in is a single screen, free-to-play puzzle game where a cat waits outside a door that's connected to a series of levers or pulleys that a ball must make contact with to activate and open. In each stage, the ball (or sometimes several) begins suspended in the air and the game paused. Given a limited, pre-set selection of items, you must place and position these items to allow the ball to get from its starting point to the handle that will then open the door, interacting with any objects it needs to or collecting the optional three stars along the way. Unpause the game and let the ball do its thing, hoping that you've placed everything for it to hit all its targets. If you haven't, simply pause/reset it again and tweak the positions of your placements until you've found the right ones, then do it all again in the next stage.

There's a nice choice of different objects to play around with, from basic ramps or simple books to knock over or additional, bigger balls to hit multiple targets, to slightly more adventurous items like springs or conveyor belts. When I first looked at the game on the Store page I was a little worried that the wealth of choice and freedom to place anything wherever you wanted would be overwhelming. That, when given so many options, you really wouldn't be able to choose any and would be left scratching your head wondering what to do with everything and where it should go. But, thankfully, between the limited number of items you're given for each puzzle, and the already laid out, fixed starting structures in every stage, it's set up in such a way that you'll at least have some vague direction of what to do in most levels, and the real challenge will be finessing the precise placement to make the ball go exactly where you want it to. It also helps that there are multiple ways to complete most stages, and in many cases, if you're crafty (or lucky) enough it's possible to do it using only a single item.

The three stars you can collect in every stage act as the game's currency which can be used to purchase hints. Well, I say hints, it actually auto places all the objects so all you have to do is unpause and watch the puzzle play itself. Or if that's too cheap for your liking, you can always use them to buy extra items to merely make things a little easier on yourself. Or better yet, if you just really like cats, they can be used to unlock more, as well as some snazzy little clothing accessories for them. As well as collecting stars in-game, you can also purchase them with real money (some of the proceeds of which apparently go to charity), but unless you're really bad at the game, or really intent on making those kitties look fab-u-lous, I always found the case to be that I had an abundance of them and never had to pay a single penny to complete the game. Well, sort of complete it.

As it stands right now at time of writing, the game hasn't been updated in almost six months, and the promised additional puzzles have yet to materialise and the developers nowhere to be seen either here or on its App Store page where it's also available. There could be many perfectly good reasons why the developer hasn't been able to get around to working on it in a while, but until proven otherwise, you should probably consider the game to be abandoned for now and impossible for achievement hunters to legitimately complete as a result. For everyone else, they probably won't care and will be happy with the 143 stages that are available and the many free hours of play they'll be able to get out of it.

Have you ever wondered what would happen if left alone in a large house with nothing to distract you than your cat?

This seems like Yet-Another-Physics puzzle game, but don't be fooled.  This is a meditation on the ennui of an elderly woman driven mad by grief and loneliness.

Day after day of letting the cat in and out of the house, she passes the time trying despretly to save the landscapes of her mind by building little puzzles to solve.  A book shelf here, some twine and pullies there.  Who's to say she can't?  No one visits her and so no one can see.

You're able to buy other cats, but never at the same time.  You can dress the cats with stars you either win or buy via micro-payment.  See, after enough time, the old woman forgets what her cat even looks like.  Its personality may change like it's clothes and the weather, but it still wants in and Grandma needs new ways to keep from going mad.

The number of levels is many, growing upwards and upwards.  She only bought a two story house.  Why are there so many floors?  Is the house building itself?  Are the puzzles building themselves?  So many stairs, thinks the old woman.  My hip could never take that many stairs.

So, in summery, this isn't just another clone of the incredible machine.  This is a masterpiece of psychological expression.  Maybe, one day at the top of the tower, you might save this poor old woman from the labyrinth of her mind.

Or get lost yourself.

Have you ever wondered what would happen if left alone in a large house with nothing to distract you than your cat?

This seems like Yet-Another-Physics puzzle game, but don't be fooled.  This is a meditation on the ennui of an elderly woman driven mad by grief and loneliness.

Day after day of letting the cat in and out of the house, she passes the time trying despretly to save the landscapes of her mind by building little puzzles to solve.  A book shelf here, some twine and pullies there.  Who's to say she can't?  No one visits her and so no one can see.

You're able to buy other cats, but never at the same time.  You can dress the cats with stars you either win or buy via micro-payment.  See, after enough time, the old woman forgets what her cat even looks like.  Its personality may change like it's clothes and the weather, but it still wants in and Grandma needs new ways to keep from going mad.

The number of levels is many, growing upwards and upwards.  She only bought a two story house.  Why are there so many floors?  Is the house building itself?  Are the puzzles building themselves?  So many stairs, thinks the old woman.  My hip could never take that many stairs.

So, in summery, this isn't just another clone of the incredible machine.  This is a masterpiece of psychological expression.  Maybe, one day at the top of the tower, you might save this poor old woman from the labyrinth of her mind.

Or get lost yourself.
